title: 103_hr2352
content: BASELINE BASED ON PRIOR YEAR'S OUTLAYS. The President's Budget includes estimated expenditures and proposed appropriations for each function and subfunction in the current fiscal year, as well as for the fiscal year for which the budget is submitted. It also provides a comparison of expenditure levels between the two fiscal years. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to require that the starting point for budget deliberations be the estimated outlays for the current year in each function and subfunction, with any increases or decreases in the congressional budget for the next fiscal year based on those estimated levels. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to require a comparison of current fiscal year spending levels with proposed spending for subsequent years, along with the percentage increase or decrease for each function and subfunction. This includes information on outlays for the current year and decisions made for funding in the following years. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to require the Director to submit a report to the Committees on the Budget of the House of Representatives and the Senate by February 15 each year. The report includes estimated budget outlays for the current fiscal year, projected outlays for entitlement programs for the next fiscal year, alternative revenue levels, budget authority, outlays, tax expenditures, and economic factors. The Director is required to submit a report to the Committees on the Budget of the House of Representatives and the Senate by February 15 each year. The report includes estimated budget outlays, projected entitlement program outlays for the next fiscal year, alternative revenue levels, budget authority, outlays, tax expenditures, and economic factors. The text chunk "SEC. 2. SUNSETTING OF ENTITLEMENTS." is a concise statement regarding the sunsetting of entitlements. Reauthorization of Discretionary Programs and Unearned Entitlements: Spending authority for unearned entitlements and high-cost discretionary programs will be terminated if not reauthorized after the enactment of this Act in fiscal year 1994 and for discretionary spending programs in fiscal year 1995. The term "unearned entitlement" refers to entitlements not earned through service or contributions. The term "high-cost discretionary program" refers to the most expensive one-third of discretionary programs within each budget function account. A point of order prohibits considering any bill that appropriates funds without prior authorization by law. Waiver or suspension of this rule requires a two-thirds vote. Decennial Sunsetting requires the termination of spending authority described in subsections (a)(1) and (a)(2) on the first day of the fiscal year beginning in the first decennial census year after 2000 and every 10 years thereafter unless reauthorized. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to eliminate emergency spending for discretionary caps.
